blocks.content: My second weekend trip in Japan was a Fuji bullet hike. We had to go before the short summer window closed. The idea came up on Thursday night. On Friday afternoon we left work early, rode three hours to Fuji, and got ready to hike. We arrived just before the lone restraunt closed while other hikers weren’t so lucky. At 10pm we started the climb so we’d be there for sunrise.

photos.caption: Finding the way to hotel in Kawaguchiko
FujiQ highlands from the coach home

blocks.content: At the summit we took shelter from the wind inside a small wooden shack. Hikers huddled over bowls of miso soup for warmth. A server guided a few locals to sit beside us, leaned in, and quietly asked them to take the seats next to the gaijin-sama.

photos.caption: Most Japan weekends ended up with this return view to Tokyo
Tokyo's snow dominates the view at Hakone
Tokyo landing, one of my earliest shots in Japan

blocks.content: Winter skies around Tokyo are the clearest. Fuji dominates the landscape because you see everywhere, and yet it’s so enormous it fades into the background like a fixed landmark. I started photographing it every time it appeared. My camera roll is full of Fuji.
